attributes.action: Overturn the TREASON verdict against Mary Queen of Scots
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
One of Mary's objections to the court's legitimacy was that its procedure was that of a treason trial.
She was not allowed a lawyer, she was not able to call any witnesses, and she was not allowed to use notes or examine any documents in the course of conducting her own defense.
Mary said ' I knew not Babington. I never received any letters from him, nor
wrote any to him. I never plotted the destruction of the Queen. If you want to
prove it, then produce my letters signed by my own hand.
Council replied ' But we have evidence of letters between you and Babington'.
Mary told him ' If so, why do you not produce them? I have a right to demand to see the originals and the copies side by side. 


She pointed out sharply to the court that her secretaries had not been called as witnesses and so could not be cross-examined.

She was forced to defend herself without being allowed to subject any of the documents exhibited against her to legal or forensic scrutiny.

reasons: Outside the remit of the Prime Minister and Government
